The Decentralized Web Could Help Preserve The Internet's Data For 1,000 Years. Here's Why We Need IPFS To Build It. ...  Coward , 5 May 2020 @ 4:40pm In fact, I want to make a bold prediction: in the next one to two years, we're going to see every major web-browser shipping with an IPFS peer, by default. That is indeed bold. I heard a similar prediction about Tor during the Snowden days. Didn't happen. I don't really get what's special about IPFS. Seems pretty similar to Freenet from 2 decades ago. Despite the claim IPFS is "more private", I see no information on the site about that. It looks kind of like BitTorrent to me, and it's well known that strangers can see what you download over BT. However, Malone's ambitions in Europe were dealt a blow in October when Liberty was forced to scrap its attempted $6.4 billion sale of its Swiss cable business UPC to Sunrise SRCG, -0.64% after Germany's Freenet — Sunrise's biggest shareholder with 25% of the stock, vociferously opposed the deal. For Telefnica, the deal comes just six months after the company announced a sweeping restructuring of its business designed to focus investment on its four key markets: Spain, Brazil, and the U.K. and Germany, where it trades under the O2 brand.
